Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Situation2: They develop a comprehensive design for a hospital wing, ensuring critical areas like operating rooms and emergency routes function seamlessly.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, tracing the lines of the new hospital wing. Every detail mattered—emergency routes, the flow between operating rooms, the placement of every door and window. My phone buzzed again, a message from my granddaughter: “Grandpa, did you see my new office? I got the job!” She’d sent photos, her smile beaming through the screen. I knew she wanted to talk, to share her excitement, maybe even hear a few words of pride from me. But the hospital project deadline loomed, and every minute counted. The team depended on my decisions to keep the design functional and safe. Yet, my family expected me to be present, to celebrate milestones and keep our bond strong. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, my heart tugged toward her joy, my mind anchored to the task at hand. I stared at the phone, torn between answering her call and finishing the plans, feeling the ache of wanting to be everything to everyone, knowing I couldn’t.
